div.ab: Lettres of this tenour to the Lord Maiour of London, the Iustices of the peace of the Counties of Midlesex and Surrey. By occasion of some Complaintes that of late haue bin made vnto vs of the multitude of houses seruinge for Common stage playes in and aboute the Citty of London, and of the greate abuses and Disorders growen by the ouermuch haunte and resorte of many licentious people vnto those houses and places, We haue entred into Consideracion of some fitt course to be taken for redresse of the saide disorders by suppressing dyuers of those houses and by some restrainte of the imoderate use of the plaies, ffor which cause Wee haue sett downe certaine orders to be duely henceforth obserued, and kept, a Copy whereof we sende yow hereinclosed, and haue sent the like to the Lord Maiour of London. and to the Iustices of the peace of Middlesex. But as wee haue done our partes in prescribinge the orders so vnlesse yow perfourme yours in lookinge to the due execution of them, we shall loose our labour, and the wante of redresse must be imputed unto yow, and others vnto whome it apperteyneth. And therefore wee doe hereby authorize and requir you to see the saide orders to be putt in execucion, and to be Continued as yow Do wish the Amendement of the aforesaide abuses, and will remoue the blame thereof from yourselues./. And so &c.

Two Lettres of one tenour to the Iustices of Middlesex & Surrey. It is in vaine for vs to take knowledg of greate abuses & Disorders complayned of and to giue order for redresse, if our Directions finde no better execution and observation then it seemeth they Do: and wee must needes impute the fault and blame thereof to yow or some of yow the Iustices of the peace that are put in trust to see them executed and perfourmed; whereof wee may giue you a plaine instance in the great abuse contynued or rather encreased in the multitude of Plaie howses and Stage Plaies in and about the Cittie of London. ffor whereas about a year & a half since (vpon knowledge taken of the great enormities and disorders by the overmuch frequentinge of Plaies) wee did carefullie sett Downe and prescribe an order to be observed concerninge the number of Playhowses, and the vse and exercise of Stage plaies with lymytacion of tymes and places for the same, (namely that there should be but two howses allowed for that vse, one in Middlesex called the Fortune ,Fortune: in italic script and the other in Surrey called the
Globe ;Globe: in italic script and the same with observacion of certaine daies and times as in the said order is particularly expressed) in such sorte as a moderate practice of them for honest recreation might be contynued, and yet the inordinate concourse of dissolute and idle people be restrained; wee do now understande that our said order hath bin so farr from takinge dew effect, as in steede of restrainte and redresse of the former disorders the multitude of play howses is much encreased, and that no daie passeth over without many Stage plaies in one place or other within and about the Cittie publiquelie made; The defaulte of perfourmaunce of which said our said order, we must in greate parte the rather impute to the Iustices of the peace, because at the same tyme wee gave earnest direction vnto you to see it streightly executed; and to certifie vs of the execution; and yet we haue neither vnderstoode of any redresse made by yow nor receaved any Certificate at all of your procedinges therein; which default, or omission, wee do now pray and require yow foorthwith to amende; and to cause our said former order to be putt duely in execution; and especiallie to call before yow the Owners of all the other Play howses (excepting the two howses in
Middlesex, Middlesex: in italic script and
Surrey Surrey: in italic script aforementioned); and to take good and sufficient bondes of them, not to exercise vse or practise, nor to suffer from henceforth to be exercised, vsed or practized any Stage playinge in their howses, and if they shall refused to enter into such Bondes, then to Comitt them to prison, vntill they shall conformed themselues. And so &c.

A lettre to the Lord Maiour & Aldermen of London. Wee haue receaued a lettre from yow, renewing a Complaint of the great abuse and disorder within and about the Cittie of London, by reason of the multitude of Playhowses , and the inordinate resort and Concourse of dissolute and idle people daielie vnto publique Stage plaies; for the which information, as wee do commende your lordship because it betokeneth your Care and desire to reforme the disorders of the Cittie; So wee must lett yow know, that wee did muche rather expect to vnderstand that our order (sett downe and prescribed about a yeare and a half since for reformation of the said disorders vpon the like Complaint at that tyme) had bin duelie executed, then to finde the same disorders and abuses so much encreased as they are. The blame whereof, as wee cannot but impute in greate part to the Iustices of the peace or some of them in the Counties of Middlesex and Surrey, who had speciall direction and charge from vs to see our said order executed, for the Confines of the Cittie, wherein the most part of those Playhowses are scituate, So wee do wishe that it might appeare vnto vs that any thinge hath bin endeavoured by the Predecessors of yow the Lord Maiour and by yow the Aldermen for the redresse of the said enormities, and for observation & execution of our said order within the Cittie; Wee do therefore once againe renew hereby our direction vnto yow (as we haue donne by our lettres to the Iustices of Middlesex and Surrey) concerninge the observation of our former order: which wee do praie and require yow to cause duelie and dilligentlie to be put in execution for all poyntes thereof, and especiallie for the'xpresse & streight prohibition of any more Playhowse then those two that are mentioned & allowed in the said Order
Order:Order: also written as a catchword at the foot of p 514 Charging & streightlie comaunding all suche persons as are the Owners of any the howses vsed for Stage plaies within the Cittie; not to permit any more publique Plaies to be vsed, exercised, or shewed from hencefoorth in their said howses; And to take bondes of them, (if yow shall finde it needefull) for the performaunce thereof; Or if they shall refuse to enter into bonde, or to obserue our said order, then to committ them to Prison vntill they shall conforme themselues therevnto. And so praying yow as yourself do make the Complaint and finde the ennormitie, so to applie your best endeav ours endeav:
letters lost in gutter to the remedie of the abuse, wee bidd &c.

body.head: p 268* (12 February) ( Privy council order for enquiry into Shrovetide disorders)

div.ab: A Lettre to his Maiesties Lieutennaunts of the Countie of Middlesex./

It is well known vnto yow what disorder and tumulte was comitted the Last
Shroue Tuesday Shroue Tuesday: 4 March 1616/17 in diuers partes aboute the Cittie by the Apprentices and other Leude and ill affected persons to the great disturbaunce of his Maiestes peace, and the hurt of many poore men. And though divers of the offendors were committed to Newgate, and proceeded withall at the Sessions accordinge to Lawe: yet they are soe farr from beinge warned by that example as they rather take occasion thereby in regarde that some of their ffellowes were in dainger and punished the last yeare, to cast sedicious lybells into Playhouses in the name of some London [ ffellowe Apprentices, to Summon others in the Skirtes, and Confynes, to meete at the ffortune, and after that to goe to the Playhouses the Redd Bull, and the Cock Pitt, which they haue designed to rase, and pull downe: besides what further mischiefe may ensue therevpon to the Scandall of Government, and the great contempt of his Maiestes Lawes. ffor prevention whereof wee thinke it very expedient As wee haue addressed our Lettres to the Lord Mayour and Alderman of ʌ the Cittie of London, soe to require yow by virtue of his Maiestes Commission of Lieutennancye directed vnto yow to take the like Order vpon
Shroue Tuesday next,Shroue Tuesday next: 17 February 1617/18 as you did vpon May day last, by settinge good and substanciall watches in such places as shalbe meete and by appointinge some of the trained Baundes to be mustered and trained that day in such convenient places in the Skirtes, and Confynes of the Cittie, as may serue for the suppressinge of any Ryott, or tumulte, that may happen by the disorder of such leude people. Whereof Wee require yow to haue a speciall care And soe &c.//
An other of the like tenour to the Lord mayour and Aldermen of the Cittie of London requireing them to take speciall, and effectuall order, that every man within their Iurisdiccion, doe keepe in their Servaunts , and Apprentices, and not suffer any of them togoe abroade that day, and to sett a good, and stronge watch at each Gate, and such other places, as shalbe meete: And withall to haue either the millitary Bande , or some competent nomber of the rayced Bande in a readines for the Suppressing of any tumultuous disorder that shall happen in that kinde./
The date is represented only by the figure '12'; February is supplied from the previous and subsequent entries; the privy council had met on 11 February 1617/18.

body.head: p 752 (14 April) ( Privy council order to restrain plays due to plague)

div.ab: It was this day ordered by the Board, in regard of the great apprehension and appearaunce of the increase of the Sicknes; that all Stage Playes, Bearebeatinges, and all manner of Assemblies for sportes, or Pastimes, shall bee forbidden; and their Lordships doe hereby pray and require the Lord Chamberlaine of his Maiestes househould, to take effectuall order, to suppresse and prohibite the same accordingly

body.head: p 144 (10 May) ( Privy council order: suppression of plays due to plague)

div.ab: His maiestie being this day present in Councell, & takeing into consideracion how dangerous it mought be in theise tymes of Infeccion to suffer the vsuall Assemblies and confluence of people at Play houses, Hath thought fitt and ordered that the Lord Chamberlaine of the Queenes maiestes Household , should be hereby prayed & required to cause the Players, that are her maiestes Servantes to forbeare all Stage Playes, & other Enterludes whatsoeuer vntill further order.

His maiestie being this day present in Councell , & takeing into Consideracion how dangerous it mought be in theise tymes of Infeccion to suffer the vsuall Assemblies of and Confluence of people at Playhouses Showes & other Spectacles haue thought fitt and ordered, that the Lord Chamberlaine of his maiestes Househould should be hereby prayed & required to cause all Stage Playes, Enterludes Showes & Spectacles whatsoeuer, to be forth with suppressed vntill further order./

In the now lost office book of Sir Henry Herbert, master of the Revels, he notes that at this time the number of plague dead had increased to four (probably an error for forty-one) within the City and fifty-four in all. Warrants were received from the lord chamberlain for the suppression of plays and these were served on the 'four' playing companies on 12 May 1636. On the 23 February 1636/7 the number of deaths had decreased to forty-four, and so the players were at liberty to perform again from the next day. However, the number of deaths rose in the summer, and so the players had to cease again until the 2 October. It is not clear if the four playing companies included those in the Middlesex theatres. The privy council also issued an order to the master of the Bear Garden for the suppression of 'all Beare baiteinges, & other sportes vsed there,' ie, in Southwark, Surrey (p 143). These orders were reiterated on 1 March 1636/7, and included rope dancing (PC2/47, p 211).

head.title: Letter from William Wilson to Edward Alleyn (A)

body.head: pp 46—7 (October) ( Letter from William Wilson to Edward Alleyn)

div.ab: Right worshipfull, my humble dutie remembred – hoping in the Almightie of youre health & prosperety, which on my knees I beseeche him long to contyneue, ffor the many favours which I haue from tyme to tyme received by poor abillety is not in the least degree able to give you satisfaction, vnless as I and myne haue byn boudnen to you for your many kyndnes soe will wee duringe life pray for your prosperety. I confess I haue found you my cheifest frend in midest of my extremeties, which makes me loath to presse or request your favour any further, yet for that I am to be married on Sunday next, & your kindnes may be a great help & furtherance vnto me towards the raisinge of my poore & deserted estate, I am enforced once agayne to entreat your worshipps Letter to mr Dowton & mr Edward Juby to be a meanes that the Company of players of the ffortune maie either offer at my wedding at St Saviors church, or of their owne good natures bestowe somthinge vppon me on that day. And as ever I and myne will not only rest bounden vnto youryour worshipps your: probably for your worshipps but contyneually pray for your worshipps health with encreas of all happynes longe to contyneue. In hope of your worshipps favour herin, I humbly take my leave. Resting

your worshipps during
life to be commanded
William Wilson

head.title: Bill of Complaint in Cane v. Wintershall

ab.note: TheHall: written to the left of the centred heading
ab.hi: To the right Honorable the Lords Commissioneres for the Custody of the greate Seale of England./

div.ab:
Humbly complaneinge shouith vnto your good Lordshipps your daylie Oratour Andrew de Caine of London Gouldsmith That whereas your Oratour with seuerall others about one & thirty yeares since or vpwards entred into an obligacion of eighty pound as is pretended vnto one Richard Gunnell late while hee lived of the Parish of St Giles Cripplegate in the County of Middlesex gentleman deceased condicioned for doeing of some collaterall thing in some short time after the day, which was done & the bond thereon discharged accordingly ought to haue binne deliuered vp & cancelled and the said Richard Gunnell knoweing the same & that noe money was due or payable thereon vnto him frequently promised to deliuer vp the same to your Oratour as soone as hee could finde it haueing mislayd the same & neuer sued your Oratour nor made any demaund thereon of your Oratour in all his lifetime which continued for many yeares togeather albeit your Oratour did for all that space frequently conuerse with the said Richard Gunnell, and that his place of aboade was allsoe dureinge that time uery well knowne to the said mr Gunnell & your Oratoures person & estate both were & respall for a greater summe of money wherefore your Oratour well hoped to haue binn noe further questioned or troubled vpon or about the said Obligacion but to bee freed thereof as it was very equall & conscionable hee should bee, But now soe it is May it please your good Lordshipps, that the said Richard Gunnell have made his last will & Testament beareing date on or about & thereof ʌmade William Wintersall & Margarett his wife william Clarke and Ann his wife & Iohn Robinson or Elizabeth ʌ Robinson his wife Robinson ʌhis Executors or Executrix hee the said Richard Gunnell on or about the yeare of our Lord 1634.\ deceased, by & after whose decease the said Elizabeth Robinson the Executrix or the said Executoures proued the said will in due form of Law and tooke vpon her or them the Execucion thereof or the said william wintersall & thereof named Executour are the Executoures of the said Elizabeth Robinson deceased the Executrix of the said mr Gunnell & haue proved her said Will and vndertaken the Execucion thereof or by some other wayes doe make Title to the said bond by & vnder the said Richard Gunnell & haueing by meanes & color of the said Executourshipp or other title found out the said oblicaions among the ould papers of the said mr Gunnell or Elizabeth Robinson and thereby gotten the same into their or one of theire handes haue of late combineing & confederateing togeather most vnconscionably ʌconceiued an Accion of debt on the same against your Oratour in the Sheriffs Court of London and doe proceed thereon withall Extremity against your Oratour threateninge to recouer the penaltie thereof against him albeit the same bee of that Antiquity and that noe suite or demaund hath euer beene made or money lent thereon as aforesaid And the better to color their proceedings the said Confederates doe now pretend & give forth that the said obligacion is condicioned for payment of 40 li. absolutely on a short Day after the Date thereof vnto the said Richard Gunnell his Executoures or Assignes and not for performance of Couenantes or doeing any other Act whereas if it bee absolutely for payment of money the same is since payd & the bond discharged in equity or noe money was euer lent or payd or euer intended to bee secured thereon but the said bond was onelie entred into by your Oratour and the said other oligors oligors: for obligors being then the then prince of Wales his servantes that played & Acted at the fortune play house in Golding Lane in the County of Middlesex vnto the said Richard Gunnell another of the said Princes then servantes & Players in the same house onely to obleige themselues to the said mr Gunnell to stay & play there, it being vsually for them to become mutually bound to each other in like manner, for that they were aduised a covenant to play there would not binde them, And it was Agreed betwixt your Oratour the said other Obligors and the said mr Gunnell that noe money (Notwithstandinge the said bond was absolute) should) bee payd thereon vnlesse your Oratour & the said other Obligours by discontinueance or departure should breate the Company which neither of them did it being allsoe customary for the said mr Gunnell and the rest of the said late Princes servantes to doe & agree to the like Tearmes, And yet the said confederates would now most vniustly after all this time and vpon soe Ancient a bond arrest from your Oratour the penalty thereof contrary to all equity & good conscience In tender consideracion whereof and to the intent the said Confederates may sett forth theireprecise & particular claime & title to the said bond & how they came by it & first saw or heard of it and by what meanes & when the said Testatour Gunnell dyed and the meanes names of the other obligors and that they may Answere all & singular the premisses that soe vpon the sdiscouerey of the trueth thereof your Oratour may bee releiued in the premisses in this Honorable Cort where matters of this nature against Ancient specialty are properly releiueable & in the meane time may haue an Iniuncion for stay of all proceedings at Law vpon the said bond accordinge to equity & good conscience and the Iustice of this Honorable Court in like cases vsed & Extended May it therefore please your good Lordshipp: to graunt vnto your Oratour his Highnes the Lord Protectores writ of subpena to bee directed to the said
William Wintersell and Margarett his wife thereby Comaundinge them att a certaine Day and vnder a certaine paine therein to bee lymitted to bee and personally to appeare before your Lordships in this Honorable Court to Answere all and singuler the premisses, and to stand to & abyd such order therein attatt: for as to your Honoures shall seeme most agreeable to equity and good conscience, And your Oratour as in all duty bound shall dayly pray for your Honou.rs./
warrde
Geoorge Cotton.

head.title: Answers in Cane v. Wintershall

body.head: mb 1 (1 November) (Answers of William and Margaret Wintershall)

div.ab:
All aduantages of Exception to the incertainty and insufficiency of the sadid bill of Complaint to these defendants now and at all times heereafter saued and reserued for answere therevnto They these defendants and either of them saith that Richard Gunnell in the bill named being in his life time and at the time of his death possessed of a personall estate of good ualue consisting of ready money and debts secured by bonds and otherwise and of other goods and chattels and hauing issue by Elizabeth his wife two daughters Margaret and Anne about twenty one yeares since dyed intestate after whose death the administration of the said personall estate was committed vnto Elizabeth Gunnell the relict of the said Richard Gunnell who hauing taken uppon her the administration of the said intestate her husbands estate amonge diuerse other goods and Chattells left at the time of her death unadministred a principall debt of forty poundes of lawfull money secured by an obligation or writing obligatory bearing date the last day of Aprill one thousand sixe hundred Twentyfoure Twentyfoure: written over erasure wherein the said Complainant by the name of Andrew Caine of London Gentleman by which name the said Complainant was then commonly called and knowne together with Charles Massey William Cartwright William Stratford Richard Price and Richard ffowler of London Gentlemen became Iointly and seuerally bound unto the said Richard Gunnell the intestate in the penall summe of eighty pounds of lawfull English money conditioned for the due and true payment of the summe of forty pounds of like lawfull money at one whole and entire payment on the first day of October next ensuing the date of the said obligation or writing obligatory as by the said obligation or writing obligatory vnder theire handes and seales ready to bee produced doth and will appeare and hauing made her last will and testament in writing and of her said last will and testament constituted ordeined and made the said Margaret and Anne her said daughters executrixes about seauen or eight yeares after the death of the said intestate her late husband and hee this defendant hauing married and taken to wife the said Margaret and William Clerke in the bill named hauing married and taken to wife the said Anne and amonge diuerse other obligations and writings obligatory and other papers and writings the said obligation or writing obligatory ʌin witch wich: c written over t the said Complainant standeth bound as aforesaid after the death of the said Elizabeth by uertue of the last will and testament of the said Elizabeth came to these defendants handes and the said defendants and either of them further saith that after the said obligation and writing obligatory came to theire hands in manner as aforesaid being informed that they the said Margaret and Anne being the daughters of the said Richard Gunnell and Elizabeth his wife and neerest of kindred unto them had the best right unto and interest in the money secured by the said obligation ʌand that the sume and euery parte thereof was vnpayd after the death of the said Elizabeth who as the said the said: written over erasure defendants haue beene informed and hope to make appeare by good proofe hauing taken to husband Iohn Robinson in the bill named did by and with him in her lifetime often demaund the said debt and damages due for the same and threatned to put the said bond in suit and endeauoured to procure the payment thereof though without effect by reason of the death and insoluency of the said obligors they the said defendants from time to time for many yeares after the death of the said Elizabeth did make demaund also of the said debt and damages due for the same and did also often endeauour to procure the payment thereof but without any successe therein by reason of the death and insoluencie of the said obligors and ʌthe absence of the said Complainant who being at Oxford in the late kinges armie could not bee proceeded against uppon the said bond in any legall way And the said defendants and either of them further saith that the said [ defendant Anne Clerke being lately dead and the right unto the said money secured by the said obligation or writing obligatory being deuolued to the said defendant Margaret and they being lately informed that the said Complainant who neuer since the said obligation came to this defendants hands untill this…untill: written over erasure of late within a yeare or two or thereabouts was of ability to make satisfaction for the said debt and damages or in any condicion to make payment of the said debt the said defendant Margaret for to inable them to recouer the said debt and damages so longe due as aforesaid and now of right belonging unto them hath of late taken letters of administration of the goods chattels debts and credits of the said Richard Gunnell her late father unadministred by the said Elizabeth her late mother as by the said letters of administration under the seale of the court for probate of wills and granting letters of administration bearing date the nine and twentieth day of September in the yeare of our lord God according to the computation aforesaid one thousand sixe hundred fifty foure ready to bee produced doth and will appeare and the said defendants further say that they being by uertue of the said letters of administration rightfully and legally intituled unto and interessed in the said debt and damages and hauing often demaunded the same of the said Complainant who refused to make payment thereof or to giue them the said defendants any satisfaction concerning the same they these defendants for the recouery of the said debt and damages haue commenced a suit uppon the said bond in the Sheriffes Court of London and did proceed thereupon as they conceiued was lawfull for them so to doe the same being a iust and due debt and rightfully belonging to them and vnsatisfied as they haue beene informed and humbly conceiue that the Allegation in the said bill of Complaint that the said debt is of great antiquity is no good cause in equitie to barre them of their said iust and due debt and damages And the rather because there was no hopes or possibility of recouering the said money at any time since the said bond came to these defendants hands till now of late by reason of the Complainant absenting himselfe and his insoluencie and the death and insoluencie of the rest of the said Obligors and these defendants and either of them further saith that they doe not beleiue that the said obligation or writing obligatorie was entred into for the doing some collaterall act which is performed and that the said bond was thereuppon discharged and ought to haue beene deliuered upp or that the said Richard Gunnell knowing the same and that no money was due and payable thereon unto him did at any time promise to deliuer upp the same to the said Complainants asso so: written over as soone as hee could find the same being mislaid or that the said Richard Gunnell did not demaund the same of the said Complainant during his life or that the said Complainants estate was sufficient to to satifsfie satisfie: second s written over f the said debt or a greater summe as in and by the said bill of Complaint is pretended and alleadged and these defendants are the rather induced soe to doe for that they doe belieue & And & And: dittography hope to make it appeare by good proffe vnto this Honorable Court that hethe he: for the said
Richard
Richard: written over another word ʌGunnell in his lifetime did often demand the said debt and after his death the said Elizabeth his said Administratrix and Iohn Robinson her husband
: erased space of 14mm with fillers did alsoe often demand the said debt and that the reason why the Complainant and seuerall others of the said Obligors were not sued vppon the said bond vntill now was because of the death of some of the said Olbigors and the Insolvency of the said Complainant and such other of them as were then Liveinge And allso for that it appears by the plaintiffes owne sheweinge in his said bill that though he alleadged that the said obligacion was entred into for the doeinge of some Collaterall Act which was done and performed accordingly yet he saith that if it were for mony it was paid and alsoe saiath further that it was entred into only to oblige the said Obligors not to departe from the Playhouse in the said bill mencioned they beinge Players and the Princes Servantes as was vsuall for them to doe by which seuerall and diuerse Allegaciones which Cannot well stand together it doth plainly appeare that they are but mere suggestions and pretences not haueinge any truth or Reallity in them And alsoe for that the Condicion of the said bond is for the payement of the summe of fforty poundes at one intire payement And these defendantes for the reasons aforesaid doe not likewise beleiue there was any such Agreement concerninge the said obligacion or writeinge obligatory entred into in manner aforesaid as in and by the said bill of Complaint is suggested and alleadged, And they the said defendantes and ether of them doe deny that they or ether of them doe make any other title or Clayme to the said debt other then they and ether of them haue formerly set forth by theire said Ioint and seuerall Answers And the said defendantes and ether of them doth alsoe deny all practice Confederacy or Combinacon in any wise Chardged vppon them or ether of them in and by the said bill of Complaint for or Concerninge any of the matters in and by the said bill of Complaint suggested and Alleadged And hope the premisses Considered they shall not be hindred by the Iniunction of this Honorable Court from Recoueringe there iust and due debt and damages att the Lawe without that that any other matter thinge Clause sentence Article or Allegacion in the said bill of Complaint Conteined materialles effectuall in Lawe to be Answered vnto by theise defendantees or ether of them and not herein and by this theire Ioint and seuerall Answeres well and sufficiently Answered vnto Confessed and Avoyded trauersed or denyed is true All which these defendantes are ready to averre mainteyne and proue as this honorable Court shall Award And humbly pray to be dismissed out of the same with theire reasonable Costes and Chardges in that behalfe wrongfully and without Cause susteyned &c/././././

head.title: Interrogatories in Alleyn v. Marten

div.ab: Item whether dyd you knowe Margarete Browne deceased late the wyfe of one Iohn Browne, and whether dyd you also knowe one Edward Allen deceased fyrst husbonde of the sayd Margarete and Rychard Grove her seconde husbonde and how Longe dyd you knowe them or any of them

head.title: Deposition in Alleyn v. Marten

div.ab: Iohn Browne of the parishe of St Buttolphe without Bisshoppsgate london haberdasher of the age of lix yeres or theraboutes swourne and examined the xxiijth Daie of maie in the xxxvth yere &c

To the 2 that he did knowe Margaret Browne ment by this Interrogatory And saieth that he knewe also one Edward Allen decessed first husband of the said Margaret and likewise he knewe Richard Grove her second husband, And saieth that he did knowe the said Margaret by the space of xx yeres & vpwardes, the said Allen about xiiij yeres, and the said Grove as longe/

To the 3 that true it is the said Edward Allen was in his lief tyme, (the said Richard Grove in his lief tyme, and the said Margaret Duringe her lief tyme) after the decesse as well of the said Allen as grove was ʌwere all in possession of a certen tenement called the chapel and two gardens to the same adioyninge scituate in Bethlem within the parishe of St Buttolphe without Bisshopsgate, london aforesaid

To the 5. that true it is, there hathe bene an Award or abitrement heretofore made betwene the said defendant and
Iohn Browne ʌthis deponent and Margaret his wief concerning their righte and interest in and to the said premisses, And saieth that indeed he this deponent and the said Margaret his then wief did agree and consent to ye same award
Edward Allen of the Parishe of St Savour in Southarke in the countie of Surrey gentleman of the age of xxvij yeres or theraboutes swourne and examined the xxviijth daie of maie in the yere aforesaid

To the 2 that he did knowe Margaret Browne decessed late the wife of one Iohn Browne, And saieth that he did knowe also one Edward Allen decessed the first husband of the said Margaret, and Richard Grove likewise decessed the second husband of her, And saieth that he knewe the said Margaret from his childhode, the said Edward Allen ʌnamed in this Interrogatory he saieth remembereth him ʌyet for he died when this deponent was verie younge, And he knewe the said Richard Grove aboute x or xj yeres before his death/

head.title: Interrogatories in Beale v. Dulwich College

div.ab: Imprimis whether Doe you know ye plaintiff & Defendantes & Doe you knowe Mathias & Thomas Allen master & warden of ye Colledge att Dulwich founded by Edward Allen Esquir Deceased & howe longe have you knowne them or either of them./

Item Doe you knowe yat Edward Allen Deceased Did in May 1622. or when make a Lease of a 12th Share or parte of ye Playehouse called ye

ffortune equally to bee Devided & of the ground wherein ye ʌsaid Playehouse Playehouse: followed line fillers for 50mm standeth vnto one Edward Iackeson for ye Tearme of 51. yeares or for what Tearmes att ye Rente of 10 li. 13 s. 10 d. payeable payeable: followed by 20mm of line fillers
att ye vsuall ffeastes ʌby quarterly paymentes vnto ye said Edward Allen and his heres : 30mm of text erased

Item Did not ye said Edward Iackeson shortely after ye takeing of ye said Lease or or:written over erased letters when Departe this life & nominated Sarah his Relicte his Executrix or ʌwas shee his Administratrix & Did not shee afterwardes intermarry with one Thomas Blomefeild & Did not ye said Blomefeild & ye said Sarah on or aboute October xiijo Caroli Regis or when Mortgage ye said Lease to one Lawrence Hill for 50 li. or what other somme was lente therevpon. weare you a witnes to ye sealeinge & Delivery of ye said Deed of Mortgage & was ye same lawefully executed yea or noe & is not this ye same Deed nowe to you produced & was not there a Provisoe in ye same Mortgage yat if ye said Blomefeild Should paie vnto ye said Lawrence Hill 52 li. ye 6th of Aprill then nexte yat then ye Deed of Mortgage to be voyde & whether Did ye said Blomefeild faile in payemente of ye said 52 li. yea or noe/

Item Dou you knowe or have you hearad yat ye plaintiff plaintiff: written over erasure Iohn Beale became ingaged & howe for ye said Thomas Blomefeild for payement of ye said 52 li. to Lawrence Hill & whether Did not ye said Beale in September 1638 or when redeeme ye said Lease from Lawrence Hill to ye end to free himself from ye said Ingagementes & from a suite Commenced against him by one Rose Hill Executrix or Administratrix of ye said Lawrence Hill, what Did ye said Beale paie vpon ye redeemeinge of ye said Mortgaged Lease & to whome & when & therevpon Did not ye said Rose Hill & Blomefeild assigne over ye said Mortgaged Lease vnto ye said Beale in or about ye Moneth of ffebruary 1638 or when els, And
for howe much money, or for what consideracion was the said Assignement made
for howe…made: inserted over erased words to ye said Beale accordinge to ye tenor or purpose thereof yea or noe, & whether weare not you a witnes to ye sealeinge & Delivery thereof ʌnowe shewed ye Declared ye truthe thereof./

Item weare you by & presente att a Communicacion & when

Item weare you imployed for ye plaintiff mr Beale & for his vse to tender & paie vnto the said Mathias Allen and vnto…and: written over erased words
Thomas Allen & which of them after they had consented & agreed to accepte of ye Rente from you from you: written over erased words ʌwhich you were imployed by ye

Item what was ye reason or Cause as you beleive whie ye said Blomefeild paid not his Rente in arreare for ye Lease in question ʌwhether was it in respecte of ye greate losses susteyned by ʌhis part of the repaires of ye howse in question called ye fortune & ye restrainte ʌof playinge
d by ye Lordes of ye privy Councell or by his Maiesty himselfe, And howe long lasted such restraint. And in what yeares, and in what tymes of the yeare were the same./

Item Doe you knowe yat Blomefeild Did att anie tyme or when ʌ& vpon what tearmes leave the arreares of his said Rente att one Sweetemans house ʌthen tenante to ye ʌ leasee of the foresaid
Playehouse for ye vse of ye said defendantes defendantes: written over erasure & howe much did hee soe ʌleave lett howe longe remayned ye same in ye houes of the Defendant Sweeteman & whie was it not attempted of by the Defendantes
