head.title: Deposition of Samuel Machem in Beale v. Dulwich College

div.ab:
Thomas Roycroft
Thomas Roycroft : in italic script servant & apprentice to the plaintiff Iohn Beale , aged .19. yeres or thereaboutes sworne &c deposeth &c To the 6th Interrogatory That vpon the 27th of October Anno Domini .1639: hee was ʌwith another of his fellowe servantes by his said master the plaintiff employed & appointed to tender & pay vnto Matthias Allen in the Article named :3: quarters Rent which the plaintiff At the Michaelmas ymediatly then before was behind for A certeine share or part which he had in the house called the ffortune play howse nere Golding Lane London & the ground thereto belonging the said Matthias Allen being Master of of Dulwich ColwichCollege Colwich: for College in Surry. And this deponent with his said fellowe servant whose name was Thomas Harding did the day aforesaid tender the said money & .3. acquittances for the same to the said mr Allen . whoe saying it was not vsuall ʌwith him to signe Acquittances till he had his money. this deponent paid him the said money being the somme of :8 li.: 4 d.: ½. & then desired him to signe the said acquittances which he the said Matthias had before read approved of and promised to signe. But ast vpon that request the said Matthias called for Thomas Allen in the Article also named who was warden of the said Colledg who being come the said Matthias willed him to signe the said .3. acquittances saying it was his place office & dutie to signe the same But therevpon the said Thomas called the said Matthias aside. & the said Matthias then vpon that put vp the said .8 li.: 4 d.: ½. in a bagg. & went to the said Thomas & they twoe haueing had some a greate deale of private discourse togeather. to what effect this deponent could not vnderstand or heare the said Matthias ʌ& Thomas Allen retorned & pretended told this deponent & his said fellowe servant that the said Complainant was in arrears more then the said money. yet would never & that the said acquittances should not be signed till that was paied & would neither say what that was or when due Nor would the restore the said money. nor ʌassigne the said acquittances. Neither did the ʌsaid Matthias Allen pretend or say anie such matter ʌat all vpon his perusall of the said acquittances before he had the money ʌto the contrary but approoved thereof. & promised to signe them when the money was paid as aforesaid. the said acquittances being in full for all mony due by the said Complainant to the foresaid Michaelmas .1639: 1639: underlined which was all the money the plaintiff owed them at that tyme as this deponent beleeveth. And further then as aforesaid he cannot say to this Interrogatory. saue

head.title: Deposition of Thomas Roycroft in Beale v. Dulwich College

div.ab: Samuell Macham of the parish of St Alban Wood streete London Stationer aged .30. yeres or thereaboutes sworne &c deposeth To the fift Interrogatory That at twoe or .3. seuerall meetinges ʌwhich were had about halfe ʌ Michaemas Anno Domini .1639 peared since that tyme had between the said Complainant mr Beale . & the defendantes Mathias & Thomas Allen Master of & Wardens of the Colledg at Dulwich in Surry or one of them when they haue bene in treaty touching certeine arrears of Rent to them due by & from Thomas Blomefeild in the Article named for his part or share of the fortune play howse & certeine ground there and hearing at such hands much arguing & discourse about it. the said Master & Warden clayming the same of the plaintiff mr Beale & the said mr Beale denying payment thereof & standing vpon the point of Iustice whether hee ought to pay it or noe. At the last the said master & Wardens being by the said mr Beale vpon sight of writinges & otherwise fully satisfied of the said Complainantes p Iustice in the said Blomefeildes share & howe long he the said Complainant had held it. the said Matthias Allen (the said Thomas consenting) sayed & promised really & faithfully to the said Mr Beale that the said Mr Beale should pay noe more then from the tyme of his haueing thereof and that the said Bloomfeild should pay the former Arreares. saying. God forbid they should make any man pay any more then his due. & wished the said mr Beale not to doubt such a thing. for that they would without any more a doe sett the saddle vpon the right horse . or wordes to that very effect. which But further to any the rest of the demaundes of this Interrogatory hee cannot depose./

head.title: Deposition of John Rhodes in Beale v. Dulwich College

div.ab: Iohn Rhodes of the parish of St Buttolph without Aldersgate Cittizen & Draper of London aged .42: yeares or thereaboutes sworne etc. deposeth &c To the first Interrogatory. That hee hath knowne the plaintiff Iohn Beale :14: or :15. yeares. & Matthias & Thomas Allen who in the Article are sayed to be Master & Warden of Dulwich Colledge founded by Edward Allen Esquir named in the Interrogatory since .6. yeares or thereaboutes.

That he doth undoubtedly beleeue that the foresaid ʌ Edward Allen about Mai :1622: did by Indenture of Lease vnder his hand & seale demise a 12th part of share of the Plai howse called the ffortune nere Goulding Lane London & of the ground whereon the said howse standeth vnto ʌone Edward Jackson for :51: yeares at 10 li. 13 s. 10 d. per Annum Rent quarterly to be paid to the said Edward Allen and his heires. And the reason of this Deponentes beleeve, therein is set forth that hee hath seene A writing purporting to be the said Lease. and hath compared the same with Divers other leases of other ʌlike partes of the said howse & ground made from & by the said Edward Allen . and hath found the hand & seale of the said Edward Allen to all the same agred together wherevnto he referreth himselfe/

That hee being present at the shewing of the writing in parchment nowe shewed this deponent dated the .7th. of September 14o Caroli Regis of & also of a lettre of the 16th of August ʌin the same yeare vnto Thomas Blomefeild in the Article named who had marryed with Sarah late Relict of & Executrix ʌor Administratrix to the foresaid Edward Jackson deceased. & whoe had with the said Sara Mortgaged the foresaid Lease to one Lawrence Hill about October :13o. Caroli Regis for :50. li. payable with Interest in Aprill following & who alsoe had vpon faileing such payment forfeited the said Mortgage & after which Rose Hill. Executrix of the said Lawrence assigned the said Lease to the plaintiff Beale who redeemed the said Mortgage and hearing the said Blomefeild acknowledge the said lettre &d a&d: & written over an a; apparently to clarify that and was intended assignment produced to be signed sealed & deliuered by himself. & the said Rose respectiuely for the consideracion therein induced this deponent doth beleeve verily yat the said Mortgage was made accordingly. and that the plaintiff Beale redeemed the same, vpon payment of 54 li. to the said Rose Hill & 6 li. to the said Blomefeild. & soe became Interessed in the said 12th part according demised to the foresaid Iackson ; And to the But for further satisfaccion therein this deponent referreth himselfe to the saied
: one line of text lost due to tear along central crease line dated .4o. Octobre Regis 13o Caroli Regis to be the foresaid Deed of Mortgate. which conteineth provisions
: rest of line lost due to tear along central crease line speied, and that the said mr Beale was induced to redeeme the same to discharge himselfe from the Ingagementes which he wes in for the said Blomefeild. & from the suit brought against him by Rose Hill before named/

That the plaintiff mr Beale haueing intelligence of a meeting to be had betweene the foresaid Matthias Allen & Thomas Blomefeld for the said Allen sealing & passing a newe lease ʌto the said Blomfeild the foresaid premisses which the said Bomefeild had conveyed to the plaintiff notwithstanding the said Assignment the said Complainant with this deponent in his Company. went to the said place apointed for that meeting at the tyme designed for it. which was nere Gratious streete about Michaelmas :1639: 1639: underlined where when he came he the said Complainant expressed some hard conceit that the said Allen should Lett his Interest to Blomefeild. & shewed the forsaid Assignement & writinges to attest the truth of his tytle which the said Matthias Allen perusing & being then & there by that meanes. & by the said Blomefeildes owne acknowledgement of the truth thereof & the like throughly satisfied as himselfe affirmed that the plaintiff had good intrest in the premisses. and that in truth noe Lease thereof could be safely made to Blomefeild hee the said Allen exer addressed himselfe to the said Blomefield . & told him. that he had abused ʌhim the said Allen by misinformacones. & that he ʌthe said Blomefield had nothing to Doe with the said premisses. but went about to betray him & the plaintiff or to that effect. And averred that the said Blomefield should haue noe Lease . And did agree & conclude touching the arrears of Rent ʌfor the said premisses on the behalfe of the foresaid Colledg to this very purpose that the said Beale should pay only such Rent for the same part in question as had accrued since his Assignement & that Blomefeild should pay the Rent accruing before. & the plaintiff should be discharged thereof saying God forbid they should doe mr Beale any wrong. and then speakeing to the said Blomefield sayed further. Sir the Sadle must be sett vpon the right horse, and demanded the said arreare ʌof Rent due before the said Beales assignement from him the said Blomefeild and told him plainly that hee the said Allen expected that Rent from him. And further to this Interrogatory he remembreth not to depose saueing that he is confident the said Allen intended ʌat the tyme
aforesaid to pursue the said agreement & conclusion for that the said Allen at seuerall tymes since did demaund the Rent for the plaintiffes part of the said premisses and before the plaintiffes said assignement thereof, from the said Blomefeild himselfe and that he failing to pay the same the said Allen endeavoured to arrest him for it as much as in him lay. But since that tyme the said Blomefeild being either run away or otherwise obscured the said Allen as this deponent hath heard hath endeavoured to get the said rent from the plaintiff notwithstanding the foresaid passages to the contrary

That he cannot anything depose to this Interrogatory albeit he hath heard it read by the said deponent examiner, but conceiveth it intended for some other person or persons. & not for him to be examined vpon

That hee hath credibly heard & beleeveth that the said Blomefeild did once since the agreement in the 5th Interrogatory mencioned leave the said arreares of Rent by him Due, for the vse of the said Colledg. which one Sweeteman whoe ʌlately Dwelleds Dwelled: ed written over s vpon the ground belonging to the forsaid playhowse , & is an vndertenant of parte thereof and that the said Rent remayned which the said Sweeteman some .2: or :3: daies or thereaboutes, on which tyme the defendantes forbearing to receave the same the said Blomefeild tooke the same againe from the said Sweeteman and shortly after abscented himselfe as aforesaid. But who the defendantes received not the same this deponent certeinly knoweth not nor howe much precisely the said some soe left was. And yet doth verily beleeve the poverty of the said Bloomefeild mooved his not being earnest to pay the same arrears. ffor this deponent knoweth that the said Bloomefeild and other the sharers of & in the said play howse During the vacancy thereof not ben employing the same by playing in it by reason of the restraint commanded in that behalfe by the King & the Councellor or some of them twice in this deponentes remembrance that is to say for about A yeare & a halfe together about Anno .1636. 1636: underlined or .1637. 1637: underlined and about .4: or :5. monthes together the Last sommer together with theire Charges in repaires of the said howse haue bene much disabled in theire & weakened in theire estates and putt to great losse & detryment And is confident the said Blomefeild & the said other sharers or parte owners of the said howse susteyned aboue 350 li. in repaires & charges in vpon & about the said howse for this deponent hath seene the said Accomptes thereof; besides theire losse amongst them susteyned thereof the said restraint from playing all the said tyme which this deponent without any manner of doubt or scruple is very well satisfied in his Consscience could not be soe little as 250 li. And further to theis twoe Interrogatories he remembreth not materially to depose saueing that such the said losses have bene the vtter vndoeing of somme of the said sharers or part owners especially one Widdowe Gray. & the foresaid
Blomefeild/ &

That hee cannot any further or more or otherwise materially depose for satisfaccion of this Interrogatory to his neere best remembrance though the same hath bene fully plainly & distinctly read over vnto him by the Examiner then in his Answere to the .5th: Interrogatory he hathe already deposed. Nor saith to this wherevnto he referreth himself

That in or about ffebruary .1638: ʌor :1639: the Defendant Tobias Lisle being trusted by the sharers or partners of the said play howse vpon ʌhis request he being one of them himselfe. and having vndertaken to the rest accordingly to receave certeine incomes then accruing due to him & them and promiseing to give a Iust & true Accompt ʌof the same and not to dispose of any part thereof but his owne without theire consent did about the same tyme receave some :82 li. :1 s.:2 d: or thereaboutes of his and the said other sharers incomes A good part whereof he of his owne accord did dispose of by lending & giveing & the like ʌas he pretendes to the quantity or summe of :2 li. 6 s.: 3 d.: or thereaboutes. which money the said mr Lisle either deteyned or hath made benefitt of & ought to Accompt for to the said other sharers. the ʌand for want whereof & the Interest of the same all the said tyme the said others sharers haue bene dampnified which by computacion amounteth in the whole to .23 li.: 10 s. at least And besides that money the said mr lisle hath receaved & stopped alsoe since that tyme .some :7 li.: 10 s. more belonging to some particuler sharers of the said howse which he is to satisfy & accompt for likewise. And further to this Interrogatory then to the .7. & 8th Interrogatories he hath sayed he cannot depose saueing that the instrument fo in the foresaid restraint from playing was Sir Henry Harbert knight master of the Revelles whoe did the same by the Mandamus of the King & Councell or some of them as before in effect he hath sayed & vndoubtedly beleeveth.

That hee doth knowe that the foresaid Sweet sharers and part owners of the foresaid play howse vpon the complaint & moane making to them made by & on the behalfe of the foresaid Sweeteman theire vnder Tenant of certeine premisses belonging to that playhowse that he was almost vndonne by reason of the foresaid restraint from playing & the like whereby (as the truth indeed is) he alsoe was a suffrer did during those tymes take from him but A ffourth part of the Rent by him payable for the premisses he held vnder them. or thereaboutes ffor whereas by his Lease thereof he was to pay them for the same after the rate of :36 li. yearly Rent. they the Sharers did during the tymes of the said restraint of playing ʌand merely for that cause & noe other take & receave from him after the rate of :10 li. [ per Annum And further deposeth not to this Interrogatory./

That hee doth alsoe very well knowe that some of the foresaid sharers or partners in the said play howse were heretofore made defendantes to A bill in this Court against them extended by or on the behalfe of the foresaid Dulwich Colledg and that they were triced in tyme & surprised in the said cause, the same being brought to hearing of A soddaine. and obt an order obteyned therevpon. before they the said sharers had examined or procured to be examined any witnes or witnesses in the said cause on theire or any of theire behalfes whereby and in regard of theire being impovered by the repaires and restraint from playing before mencioned they could not make any defence therein. And more saith not to this Interrogatory.
That hee cannot any more say to this Interrogatory then in his Answere to the 10th Interrogatory precedent he hath already deposed wherevnto he referreth himselfe/.

That hee doth knowe that the plaintiff mr Beale is and hath ever from tyme to tyme bene ready & willing to pay such Rent as as bee hath bene & is behind & vnpaied and for his particuler share or part of the foresaid play howse & premisses assigned vnto him as aforesaid ever since ʌfrom the tyme of the said Assignement making or since from the tyme of his becoming possessed thereof which was in Iune :1638: soe as the Rentes accruing due in the tymes of the foresaid Inhibicion from playing may be deducted & defalted vnto him as hee & the said other sharers abated to the said Sweeteman theire vnder tenant before mencioned. and without the said mr Beale by himselfe & this dept & others hath tendred the said Rent duly. And further deposeth not to this Interrogatory/

That hee hath heard the foresaid Matthias & Thomas Allen & the said Tobias Lisle acknowledge that they the said Allens had forbidden & that the said Lisle whoe had A lettre of Attorney from them had alsoe on theire behalfe forbidden the foresaid Robert Sweeteman the said sharers vndertenant as aforesaid not to pay any part of the Rent by him payable, to vnto the said Complainant mr Beale. and that they had declared theire reason for soe doeing to bee ʌ this vizt. that the said mr beale had not ri anie right therevnto or to the premisses in the said Sweetemans tenure or to that effect. And doth knowe that vpon such direccion the said Sweeteman did forebeare to pay the said mr Beale any part of the said Rent . which is all he saith to this Interrogatory/

That he cannot any further more or otherwise materially depose for satisfaccion of any demaundes of this Interrogatory then in his Answeare to the 11th Interrogatory precedent wherevnto hee referreth himselfe he hath already deposed./

That it is true that at or nere the Chappell of the Rolles in Chancery Lane ʌ London about Michaelmas :1640: 1640: underlined he this deponent then & there accidentally mett with Matthias Allen before ʌnamed whoe then & there. (as he had seuerall tymes before sayed) did tell relate & expresse to this deponent that hee had offered and would then consent and agree that if hee this deponent and all the sharers & part ownours of the said playhowse & premisses would be contented that the defendant Lisle or any one person whome the said sharers should appoint might be permitted to collect the Rentes of the said premisses for the foresaid Dulwich Colledg that then neither hee the said Matthias Allen. and alsoe the said Collegiattes should not only forbeare to demaund or expect any Rent for the foresaid premisses from any of the said sharers due in the tymes of the foresaid restraint from playing or the like in tyme to come of like Inhibicion But would & should alsoe wholly remitt the same
to the said sharers and never haue or expect any thing in lewe thereof. or to that very purpose. And the said Mathias Allen then & there alsoe as at other tymes before tolde this deponent that hee the said Matthias had declared such his consent & agrement to the said mr Lisle and that he the said Matthias did not hold it reasonable that the said sharers being (as indeed they are) enioyned by theire Lease of the said play howse not to convert or employ the same to any other vse then playing . & being by the higher powers forbidden playing should in such tyme of restraint pay any Rent for the said premisses and affirmed that hee the said Matthias Allen wished with all his hart that it was setled that ʌsoe the said Sharers might be sure not to pay Rent in such tymes. and affirmed that hee would forthwith goe to Councell to contrive away for the setling thereof accordingly either by an other order by consent to be entred in this Court. where the said matters were then & still are depending in question or otherwise. and that hee conceived the said order by consent to be the best way all thinges considered for that the Collegiates of the foresaid Colledge. if ʌhe the said deponent ʌ Allen should moove it to them to be Donne any other way might hapily thinck the said Allen was not soe studious for theire good as he ought to be. and wished this deponent betweene that & theire next meeting the peticion ʌto procure the Lord Keeper ʌmight to be peticoned therein. or to procure that to be Donne or what this deponent thought ʌfor the setling thereof as should be fitt ʌ ʌ: caret mark redundant therein. promising he would never oppose the same or wordes to that very effect. But as yett the same hath not bene setled in that sorte. which is all he can say to this Interrogatory./

That hee doth well remember that ʌwhen the said Matthias Allen & Tobias Lisle did as aforesaid acknowledg theire forbidding of Sweeteman to pay the plaintiff Beale any Rent, they the said Allen & Lisle did likewise confesse (as this deponent well knoweth they [ or had of them had) that they had alsoe forb wished & perswaded other of the sharers of the said play howse & premisses. as the said Lisle himselfe had Donne to stop the said mr Beales share of the money due vnto him by the Daily proceed of the said howse. and that they ʌor one of them had also pers intreated & incited the Actours in the said
playh
playh: for play house did to bring theire distinct Accions at lawe against the said mr Beale for comeing vppon the said premisses or into the said play howse , saying for theire reason of all the said incitementes & perswacions That the said mr Beale had noe right or Interest therein. and soe exceedingly traduced & vilified the said Complainant & his said tytle, the said Lisle in particuler further saying that hee blushed for shame at the said mr Beale that he should be soe impudent to come to the said play howse to Demaund any share or Interest there or to that effect. And further to this Interrogatory he cannot depose vpon his nowe best remembrance/
Capta coram ffeyton

head.title: Lay Subsidy for Ossultone, Gore, and Edmonton Hundreds

ab.hi:
ffynnesburye
ffynnesburye: in display script and Wenlaxe barne

head.title: Interrogatories in Lisle v. Dulwich College

div.ab: Imprimis doe yow knowe the plaintiffs Thomas Allen Master of Dulwich Colledge and Tobias Lisle the Defendant and how longe haue yow knowne them and either of them

Item did not yow about the yeare .1644 buy a share of the ffortune playhouse by the name of one Twelft part thereof of Thomas Barker late of London deceased and did not yow desire the Defendant Tobias Lisle that that party which dealt for the profit of thes two shares and a halfe which he was intrusted for the children of mistress Minshaw and Mr Cade should take vp the profitts of your share also and yow would pay them for their paines

Item did not yow receiue all the profitts when yow could get any either of mistress ffinney or of mistress Smith for fiue shares of the ffortune playhouse . and did not yow pay to Robert Banckes or vnto Arthur Minshaw (which was one of the children Tobias Lisle was intrusted which whichch: superscript ch presumably intended for deletion for) the profitt of two shares and a halfe And to one Mr Iohnson a souldier the profitt of one share which was Mr Barkers And the profittes of halfe a share to Mr Iames Earle and the profittes of one share more to one Robert Grimes for the share of Thomas Grimes and haue not yow bin imployed to receiue all the rentes likewise since the Defendant Tobias Lisle hath had anything to doe there at the ffortune playhouse and are not these acquittances those which Mr Iohnson and Mr Earle gaue yow vpon the payment of moneyes vnto them ʌfor the last profitts of the share and halfe share aforesaid and doe yow not beleeue the Defendant Lisle hath paid 100 li. more for repaires of the playhouse then ever hee receiued.

Item did not yow buy halfe a share of the ffortune playhouse about the yeare 1642. and did not yow desire that William ffinch which tooke vp the Defendant Lisles money should take vp yours also and yow would pay him for it

Item did not yow heare the Defendant Tobias Lisle complayne vnto Thomas Allen the now Master of Dulwich Colledge & one of the plaintiffs in this cause that the said Master did maintaine Mathew Smith to keepe possession of the said playhouse and that the said Smith did lett the said house to players and ffencers and Dancers on the rope vntill it woud bee pulled downe And the said Thomas Allen replyed the said Smith should doe so and that hee knewe a reason for it, and was not this complaint made as the said Allen came out of one Pitts his house nere the ffortune

Item did not yow and one Thomas Hoare stand by and were present when Mathias Allen the then master and Thomas Allen who was then Warden (and is now Master ) did agree with the Defendant Tobias Lisle that if the said Defendant Lisle would take two leases of two shares and a halfe of the ffortune playhouse in trust for Mary Minshaw and Susan Cades vpon such condicions as they would putt into the same and would pay so much money as then was in arreare of rent, that the said Mathias and Thomas (if the said Defendant Tobias desired it) would pay the said Defendant Lisle his money which hee then payd ʌbeing 74 li. 1 s. 0. ob. and interest for the same, and whatever other charges and damages the said Lisle should sustaine at the end of ffour yeares (that they the said master and Wardens and the rest of that corporacion might by that meanes gaine the rest of their tenantes to pay their rents the better) And did not yow and Thomas Hoare subscribe your names to this agreement in the yeare 1619. and hath not the said Lisle demaunded the said money and leases to bee delivered back, and doth not the plaintiff Thomas Allen refuse to performe this agreement.

Item doe yow not know and remember that some 8 yeares since the said Thomas Allen (who is now Master and was then warden ) did come into the house being parte of the ffortune playhouse where yow then did dwell and forbid yow to pay any rent to any of the sharers of the house meaning this Defendant Tobias Lisle or any of the rest

Item was not Mathew Smith with yow and was sworne and allowed to bee in fforma pauperis to answere a bill proferred against the said Defendant Tobias Lisle ʌSmith & other by the said plaintiffs and were not both yow and the said Smith & others served to answere to the said Bill and doe not the said plaintiffs in the said Bill stay proceding in the suit of Smith notwithstanding hee was served ʌwith a subpena and did ʌnot hee answere stand out in contempt vntill a writt of rebellion issued out against him for want of an answere And doe yow not know or haue credibly vnderstood that the said Smith by the order & appointment of the said plaintiffs haue not set and lett the aforesaid premisses called the ffortune playhouse & the appurtenances & taken the profittes of them and converted them to his & the plaintiffs or some of their & which of their vse

Item doe yow know that Mathew Smith by the order of the plaintiffes did keepe possession of the said house and premisses in question for the plaintiffs vse and did not yow heare the said Smith and his wife or one of them confess and acknowledge vnto yow after the said premisses were ruinated and pulled downe by the souldiers that the said plaintiffs did giue him or them or some of them and which of them order & direccion to keepe possession of the said premisses and to take and detaine in this custody the lead timber stuffe and other materialls then last in the said house and premisses in question and about what tyme was it that yow heard them the said Smith & his wife or either of them so speake and say.

Item did not the plaintiffs giue order to the tenantes of the said premisses in question to pay their rents to them and not to the said Defendant Tobyas Lisle or any other the Lessees of the said premisses and how long is it since the said plaintiffs did giue such order and direccion and did not yow heare Andrew CageCaine
Cage: perhaps for Caine one of the tenantes of the said premisses confesse and acknowledge that the said plaintiffs had giuen him and the rest of the tenants order to pay their rentes vnto the said plaintiffs And haue not the plaintiffs receiued the same rents. and how long haue they so receiued them as yow know or haue credibly heard or beleeue and what induceth yow so to beleeue
Item what other matter or thinge doe yow know materiall or effectuall for or on the Defendantes behalfe in this cause.

head.title: Deposition of Jane Minshaw in Lisle v. Dulwich College

div.ab: Iane Minshaw wife of Edward Minshaw of the parishe of St Gyles Cripplegate Lond in the County of Middlesex gentleman aged 28 yeares or thereaboutes sworne &c/

That shee doth very well remember that about seuven yeares since the Complainant Thomas Allen (who was then Warden but is now Master of the Colledge called Godesguift in Dulwiche) did repaire vnto this Deponentes said husbandes then Dwellinge house which was parte of the ffortune playhouse & did then & there will this Deponent being then servant vnto hir now husband to tell ʌthis Deponentes then master who is now this Deponentes hir said husband that he the said Thomas Allen did charge & warne him the said Edward Minshaw to pay noe more rent for that parte of the said house that he then lived in vnto s s: apparently the start of an uncompleted word left uncancelled any of the sharers of the said playhouse the Defendant Tobyas Lisle being then A sharer in the said house which is all that shee saith that shee can depose materially to this Interrogatory/
To the rest &c/

ab.note: X: personal sign of Jane Minshaw

div.ab: That she doth well knowe that Mathew Smith did by order of the Complainant keepe possession of the said house and premisses in question for the plaintiffes vse for this Deponent saith that the said Smith and his wife did confess and accknoweledge vnto this Deponent after the premisses were rujnated and pulled downe by the Soldiers that the Complainant did give express order to him the said Smith and his wife to keepe possession of the said premisses and to take and detaine in his ʌor their Custody the lead Timber stuff and other materialles then left in the said house and premisses in question for this Deponent beinge Tennant s about Easter last past ʌ ʌ: no insertion beinge Tenn to the said premisses goeinge about to repaire the same the said mistris Smith would not suffer this Deponent soe to doe tellinge this Deponent that shee and her husband had express order as aforesaid not to suffer the materialles thereof to be medled withall or she ʌthis Deponent to have any thinge to doe therwith./

That true it is that the Complainantes did give order ʌin this Deponentes heareinge to the Tennantes of the said premisses about 7 yeares since that they should paie their rentes to them ʌthese plaintiffes and not to the Defendant or any other and this Deeponent hath ʌalso heard Andrew CageCaine Cage: for Caine in this Interrogatory named one of the Tennantes of the said premisses confess and accknoweledge that the said Complainantes had given him and the rest of the Tennantes order to pay their rentes vnto the said Complainantes but the plaintiffes to this Deponentes knoweledge or as she verily beleeveth have not at any tyme since receaved ʌany the rentes for the the same./ and more siaeth not in this behalfe/

That she doth not to her remembance remembance: an written over other letters knowe any other matter or thinge materiall or effectuall to be deposed vnto which was may any way conduce to the benefitt of the Defendant in this Cause./

seg.note: X: personal sign of Jane Minshaw

head.title: Deposition of John Rhodes in Lisle v. Dulwich College

div.ab: Iohn Roades of the parish of St Martins in the ffeildes in the County of Middlesex Draper aged 50 yeares or thereaboutes sworne & examined deposeth and saith./

That hee doth confidently beleeue that the defendant Lisle hath payd aboue 100 li. att the least more for repayres of the ffortune playhouse in the Articls menconedmencioned menconed: for mencioned; sign of abbreviation missing then hee receiued, And this hee saieth is all that hee this Depponent cann certainely depose to and the questions of this Interrogatory./

That hee doth knowe that Matthewe Smith in the Article named did keepe possession of the said Playhouse for the vse of the Complainants, And saith that hee the said Smith did Lett the said house to Players. ffencers and Dauncers on the Rope , by reason of which the said Playhouse was pulled Downe, And more hee saieth hee cannot Depose to this Interrogatory.
To the sixth Interrogatory hee saieth hee cannott depose./

That hee this Deponent was with Matthewe Smith when hee was sworne and allowed to bee in forma pauperis to Answere a bill preferred against the said Defendant Tobias Lisle ʌ& himselfe & others by the said Complainantes, And hee saith that both hee this Deponent and the said Smith and others were served to Answere the said bill, And hee saith that hee hath heard the said Smith say that the plaintiffes in the said Bill doe stay proceedinges in the suite against smith notwithstandinge hee was served with a subpena, and saith that the said Smith did stand out in Contempt vntill a writt of rebellion issued out against him for want of an Answere, And doe you not knowe or hee saith that hee doth knowe that the said Smith by the order and appoyntment of the said plaintiffes, haue no sett & lett the afoaresaid premisses called the Fortune playhouse with the appurtenances and haue taken the profittes of them and still keepes possession of the said house for the plaintiues vse, as the said smith & his wife haue often tould him this Deponent. And more saith not to this Interrogatory nor in this behalfe./
To the rest &c.

That after the souldiers had pulled downe & ruinated the said playhouse hee this Deponent Did heare the said Smith and his wife say, that the plaintiues had given them direccion & order to keepe possession of the said premisses ʌand to take & detaine in his custody the Leade Timber stuffe Quit rentes and other materialls then Lefte in the said house & premisses in question And more saith not to this Interrogatory./ to keepe & detaine the same for the vse of the vse of the plaintiffes. And hee saith that it was about Easter Last when hee heard them the said Smith and his wife soe speake & say. And more deposeth not to this Interrogatory./

That hee this Deponent about Eight yeares agoe did heare, Andrewe Caine and the nowe wife of Edward Minshall two of the Tenantes of the said premisses say, that the plaintiues had given order to the tenantes of the said premisses in question to pay theire rentes to them the plaintiffes, and not to the defendant Lisle or anie other of the Lessees or tenantes of the said premisses And hee saith that the rentes reserved vppon the premisses & payable to the Lessees of the premisses the Defendant & others, haue been detained by the said Tenantes and not payd to the Defendant & others the Lessees to the said Complainantes as hee verilie beleeueth. And more saith not to this Interrogatory.

That hee cannot further Depose to this Interrogatory more then what hee hath allready deposed in & by his Answere to the ne precedent Interrogatories wherevnto hee hath already been examined & more saith not./

head.title: Interrogatories in Cane v. Wintershall

div.ab: Doe you knowe the parties plaintiue and Defendantes and did you knowe Richard Gunnell late of the parish of St Giles Cripplegate in the County of Middlesex gentleman deceased, and how longe is it since the said Richard Gunnell dyed declare your knowledge./

Doe you knowe or haue heard That the Complainant Togeather with Charles Massey William Cartwright William Stratford Richard Price and Richard ffowler of London gentlemen, were heretofore about thirty yeares agoe and vpwards (amongst others) Actours or Players, and did vsually act or play Comedyes and Tragedies att the then ffortune Playhouse in the County of Middlesex./ declare etc.

Doe you knowe haue you heard or Credibly beleive, or what can you say to prove That it was a vsuall & ordinary vsage and Custome vses with and amongst the Actours of that and other Playhouses in and about London, to give mutuall bonds one to another, or that two three foure of them or more did bind themselues to some one of theire fellowes in a penall summe of money, for the payment of a certaine summe of money att a Day to come, declare &c:/.

Were not such bonds given and entred into Principally, and to the end intent & purpose, to keepe the said Actours togeather that they should not breake or leaue the Company and Act att other Playhouses. And that such bonds were neuer demaunded or putt in suite, vnless vpon such departure, & leaveing theire Companye./

Haue you heard or doe beleiue, that the reason why the Condicion of such bondes were made for payment of money, and not with Condicion to keepe the players togeather, was it not because that it was held vnlawfull to binde players with such expresse Condicion that they should play att such or such a house Declare your knowledge and beleefe herein att large./

Haue you heard or doe you beleive, That the Defendant Complainant Togeather with Charles Massey William Cartwright William Stratford Richard Price & Richard ffowler , did become ioyntly and seuerally bound vnto Richard Gunnell about Thirty yeares agoe, in a bond of eighty pounds for payment of fforty pounds att a day And doe you beleive That there was anie summe or sumes of money truly and really due vnto the said Richard Gunnell vpon the said bonde declare &c./

Were and was not the said Complainants and the other obligours men of Estates and abilities to haue payd the summe of forty pounds and interest for the same, if they had beene demaunded or sued for the same, and doe you beleeue or have heard that there was euer any demaund made of the said fforty pounds by Richard Gunnell in his lifetime or by Elizabeth his wife and administratrix in her lifetime, or by the Complainant defendantes\ vntill now of late declare &c./

Did not the said Richard Gunnell & the said Obligours live togeather or neere one vnto another many yeares after the said bond was soe entred into as aforesaid, And doe you beleive that if any money was due vpon the said bond the same was longe since satisfyed and payd, & that the said bond ought to haue beene diluered vpp, declare./

Of what esteeme and Creditt in the world hath the Complainant lived in, for these Thirty yeares and vpwards, hath hee not been reputed and taken to bee a person both able and honest to pay all his iust and due debts & in what sort and fashion hath hee lived dureinge all the time of your remembrance, hath hee not vsed the trade of a Goldsmith, and sometimes a vintner and thereby mainteyned himselfe and family in good Credittt./

Hath not the said Complainant for Thirty yeares and vpwards, or how long as you remember lived Constantly in and about the Citty of London , & in what callinge or callinges. And hath hee att any time absented himselfe; if yea: when and for how longe time Declare &c./

Doe you knowe that it was a vsuall vsage and Custome with & amongst the Master & Cheefe Actours of the ffortune Playhouse and other Playhouses, To take youths and boyes to bee theire Apprentices or Covenant servants to serue & abide with them for a certaine number of yeares, And did they not vsually binde such boyes and youths as Apprentices to themselues or some others that were ffreemen of some Trade or other, And did not such boyes and servants vsually Act and play partes in Comedies and Tragedies att the ffortune and other Playhouses although such youths or boyes were not bound to Act playes by Covenant in expresse words, and were not many or some of those boyes made free of such particular Trades as theire seuerall Masters vsed besides playeinge Declare &c./
Declare what other matter or thinge cann you Depose for the benefitt of the plaintiff\

head.title: Deposition of Ellis Worth in Cane v. Wintershall

div.ab: Ellis worth of White Crosse streete in the parishe of St Gyles Cripppellgate in the County of Middlesex gentleman aged 67 yeares or thereaboutes beinge produced as A wittnes on the parte of the Complainante in this Cause was on the ffirst Day of ffebruary 1654 shewed in person to Mr &c by William Bamfeild &c And then afterwardes the same Day & yeare the said Deponent beinge sworne & examined Deposeth & sayeth./

That hee Doeth knowe the Complainante Andrew De Caine and the Defendantes William Wintershall & Margarett his wife in the tytle of the Interrogatories named And hee Did well knowe Richard Gunnell late of the parishe of St Gyles Cripplegate in the County of Middlesex gentleman Deceased in this Interrogatory Inquired of when hee was liveinge And hee sayeth that itt is aboute three or foure & Twenty yeare since the hee the said Richard Gunnell dyed, soe neere as this Deponent remembreth the tyme./

That hee doeth knowe that the said Complainante Mr De Caine together with others Charles Massey, William Cartwright William Stratford Richard Price & Richard ffowler of London gentlemen in this Interrogatory name respectiuely named (amongest others) were heretofore that is to say a thirty yeares since & vpwardes Actors or Players & Did vsually Acte & play Comedyes and Tragedyes att the then ffortune play house in the Countie of Middlesex , And more sayeth not to this Interrogatory./

That hee Doeth knowe that it was an vsuall & ordinary vsage & Custome vsed with & Amongest the Actors or Players of the ffortune & other play houses in & Aboute London, to giue Mutuall bondes one to another & for twoe or three or foure of them or more to bynde themselues to some one of their fellowes in A penall bond summe of money by bond for the payment of A Certaine summe of money att A day to come And more hee sayeth not to this Interrogatory./

That such bondes soe giuen & entred into as aforesaid were principally and to the end Intent & purpose to ge keepe the Actors together that they should not breake or leave the Company they belonged to and acte att other playhouses, And this Deponent Doeth the better know the same for that hee was and one heretofore one of the Actors an Actor or player for many yeares And hee sayeth that hee never knewe such bondes were never demaunded or put in suite, vnlesse vpon such departures or ʌthe parties soe bound leaveinge their Company And more sayeth not to this Interrogatory./

That hee this Deponent always Conteined & Doeth beleiue, that the reason why the Condition of such bondes were made for payment of money as aforesaid & not with Condicion to keepe the players together; was because for that itt was held vnlawfull to bynd players or Actors with such Expresse\
Condicion that they should play att such ʌa house or the like And further hee sayeth hee Cannott Depose to this Interrogatory./

That hee Doeth beleiue that the Complainante Andrew Can De Caine was A man of A good Estate and ma of Abillyty to haue payed the summe of forty poundes & Intrest for the same, but whether the other obligors in this Interrogatory meant & Intended were men of Estates hee Cannott say, And this Deponent Doeth not know sayeth that hee never heard that there was ever any Demaund made of the forty poundes in this Interrogatory mencioned by the said Richard Gunnell in his life tyme or by Elizabeth his wife & Administratrix in her life tyme or by the said Defendantes And further hee sayeth hee Cannott Depose to this Interrogatory./
That the said Richard Gunnell & the said obligors Did live ʌneere together aboute thirty yeares since & for many yeares after, But And further hee sayeth hee Cannot Depose to this Interrogatory./

That the said Complainante for the space of these thirty yeares last past & vpwardes ʌhath lived in good Esteeme & Creditt in the world And hath beene reputed & taken to bee A person both able & honest to pay all his Iust & due Debtes, And hath ever hee sayeth that hee the plaintiffe ever since Dureinge all the tyme of this Deponent remembrance of him, hath lived in very good sorte & ffashion & in A plentifull manner And hath vsed the trade of A Goldsmith & sometymes of Vintner & thereby mayneteyned himselfe & family in good Creditt And more sayeth not to this Interrogotory./

That hee Doeth knowe that itt was an vsall uvsage & Custome with & Amon Amongest the Masters &Cheife Actors of the ffortune Play house aforesaid & other Play houses in and aboute London, to take youthes & boyes to bee their Apprentices or Covenant servantes to serve & Abide with them for Certaine number of yeares And hee sayeth that the said Masters and Cheife Actors Did vsually bynde such boyes & youthes as Apprentices to themselfes or some others that were freemen of some trade or other And that such boyes or ʌand servantes Did vsually Acte & play partes in Comidies and Tragidyes att the fortune & other play houses although such youthes or boyes were not bound to Acte playes by Covenant in Expresse wordes And this Deponent knoweth that some of those boyes or youthes were made free of such particuler Trades as their severall Masters vsed besides playinge And more sayeth not to this Interrogatory./

That hee Cannott more say to this Interrogatory or on this behalfe to his now remembrance then what hee hath before Declared in his Answeres to the precedent Interrogatories saueinge hee sayeth that hee Doeth beleiue that the said Richard Gunnell aboute Thirty yeares since was not of ability to Lend the summe of fforty fforty: for forty pounds And this Deponent Doeth likewise belieue that hee the said Richard Gunnell in his lifetime would haue sued for the said forty the bond in question if any money thereby had beene Due vnto him And more sayeth not to this Interrogatory./
To the rest &c./ Ellis woorth

head.title: Depostion of William Hall in Cane v. Wintershall

div.ab: William Hall of Barbicon in the parishe of St Gyles Cripplegate London gentleman aged 52 yeares or thereaboutes being produced as A wittnes on the parte of the Complainante in this Cause was on the ffirst Day of ffebruary 1654 shewed in person to Mr one of the Clarkes in Mr office &c. by William Bamfeild &c And then afterwardes the same Day & yeare the said Deponent beinge sworne & Examined Deposeth & sayeth./

That hee Doeth knowe that it was an vsuall & ordinary vsage & Custome vsed with & Amongest the Actors or Players of the ʌC ffortune & other Playhouses in and aboute London, to giue Mutuall bondes one to another, & for twoe three foure of them or more to bynde themselues to some one of their ffellowes in A penall summe of money for the payment of A Certaine summe of money att a Day to come, And this Deponent sayeth that such bondes were giuen & entred into Principally, and to the end ʌIntent & purpose to keepe the said Actors together that they should not breake or leave the Company they were of and acte att other playhouses, And this Deponent Doeth the better know the same for that hee this Deponent was for many yeares an Actor or one of the Actors or players att the ffortune playhouse aforesaid and other playhouses in & aboute london and hath beene bound in such bond as
as is
as as: dittography; or second as for is aforesaid himselfe and Did observe that it was an ordinary Custome soe to doe by ʌof other Actors or Players soe to Doe, And this Deponent sayeth that such bondes were never Demaunded or put in suite, vnlesse vpon such departure from their Company & leaveinge their Company ʌthat they ʌsoe bound were of, and acte att other playhouses And more sayeth not to these twoe Interrogatories./

That hee hath heard & Doeth beleiue That the said Complainante together with the said Charles Massey William Cartwright William Stratford Richard Price & Richard ffowler, Did ʌaboute thirty yeares since become Ioyntly & severally bound vnto the aforesaid Richard Gunnell in A bond of Eighty poundes for payment of forty pounds att A day And this Deponent sayeth that hee Doeth beleiue that there was not any summe or summes of money truly & really due vpon vnto the said Richard Gunnell vpon the said bond, for that the said Richard Gunnell att the tyme of the enteringe ini that tyme to witt aboute thirty yeares agoe was but of A lowe Condition, & not of abillyty as this Deponent belieueth to lend such A summe of money as forty poundes, And this Deponent beliueth that the said bond was entred into to onely to the Intent & purpose to keepe the said Complainante [ & the other obligors that the y they: y written over another letter should not Acte att anyanoth any: written over anoth other playhouses then the fortune playhouse, though the Condicion itt not beinge held lawfull though [ the same was not made as this Deponent conteineth not with such Expresse Condicions, itt not not being held lawfull to bynd players as as aforesaid, And more sayeth not to this Interrogatory./

That the said Richard Gunnell & the said obligors Did live neere one vnto another for many yeares after the tyme of the entering into of the said bond, And this Deponent Doeth belieue that if any money were was Due vpon the said bond the same was long since satisfied & payed & that the said bond ought to haue beene Delivered vpp, but this Deponent beleiueth that the said bond was made to the per Intent & per purpose by by by by: dittography since before Declared And this with what hee hath before Declared is all hee sayeth hee to this Interrogatory./

That hee Cannott further Depos to his now remembrance More say to this Interrogatory or on this behalfe then what hee hath before declared in his Answeres to the precedent Interrogatories, saueinge hee sayeth that hee Doeth beleiue that the said Richard Gunnell in his life tyme would have Required the money ʌfrom the plaintiffe or the other obligors vpon the bond in question if any had beene Due to him, for that hee the said Mr Gunnell ʌbeinge was in A low Condition for Diverse yeares before his Decease, And this Deponent Doeth beleiue that the said bond in question was onely entred into by the plaintiffe and the others obligors to the Intent & purpose as this Deponent hath before Declared ʌby this Deponent in his Answere to the precedent 6th Interrogatory./
To the rest &c./

head.title: Deposition of John Wright in Cane v. Wintershall

div.ab: Iohn Wright of the parishe of St Gyles Cripplegate London Goldsmith aged 40 yeares or thereaboutes being produced as A wittnes on the parte of the Complainante in this Cause was on the ffirst Day of ffebruary 1654 shewed in person to Mr one of the Clarkes in Mr office whoe is Clarke for the Defendantes in this Cause by William Bamfeild &c. And then afterwardes the same Day & yeare the said Deponent beinge sworne & Examined Deposeth & sayeth./

That the said Complainante was ever since this Deponent first knewe (which is aboue 25 yeares since) of Ability to haue payed the summe of fforty poundes & Intrest for the same itt if hee had been Demaunded or sued for the same, But of what Estates or abilityes the other obligors in this Interrogatory meant & Intended were this Deponent Cannott say And this Deponent never heard nor Doeth beleiue that there was ever Demaund made of the fforty poundes in this Interrogatory mencioned by the said Richard Gunnell in his life tyme or by Elizabeth his wife and Administratrix in the Article named in her lifetyme or by the Defendantes vntill now of late, And more sayeth not to this Interrogatory./

That hee the said Richard Gunnell & the said plaintiffe & some of the said obligors as namely, William Cartwright & Richard fflowler , Did aboute 25 yeares since live neere vnto one vnto any other, And further hee sayeth hee Cannott Depose to this Interrogatory./

That hee Doeth knowe that itt was an vsuall vsage & Custome with & amongest the Masters &
players Cheefe Actors or players of the ffortune Playhouse & other playhouses in & aboute London, for them the said To take boyes & youthes to bee their Apprentices or Covenant servantes to byde serve & abyde with them for A Certaine number of yeares, And hee sayeth that the said Masters & Cheefe Actors Did vsually bynde such boyes & youthes as Apprentices to themselues or some others that were ffreemen of some trade or other, And this deponent sayeth that such boyes or youths Did Acte
& play partes in Comedyes and Tragedyes att the fortune & other playhouses although such youthes or boyes were not bound to Acte playes by Covenant in Expresse wordes, And he sayeth that such boyes many of such boyes were made free of such particuler Trades as their severall Masters vsed besides playinge, And this Deponent sayeth that hee himselfe was bound as an Apprentice to the said plaintiffe ʌfor A Certaine number of yeares whoe was & is a Goldsmith by profession to Learne the profession of trade of A Goldsmith, And hee sayeth that hee this Deponent Did vsually Acte & play partes in Comedyes & Tragedies in the tyme of fortune tyme of his
Apprenticshipp Apprenticshipp: s written over another letter and was afterwardes made free by the said plaintiffe of the Trade who of A Goldsmith which the said plaintiffe vsed, And this with what hee hath before Declared in his Answeres to the precedent Interrogatories is as much as hee Can to his remembrance Depose to these twoe Interrogatories or on this behalfe./
To the rest &c./

head.title: Deposition of Edward Cane in Cane v. Wintershall

div.ab: Edward De Caine of the parishe of St Buttolphes with Bishoppsgate London Goldsmith aged 27 yeares or thereaboutes beinge produced as A wittnes on the parte of the Complainante in this Cause was on the ffirst Day of ffebruary 1654; shewed in person to Mr one of the Clarkes in Mr office &c. by William Bamfeild &c. And then afterwardes the same day & yeare the said Deponent beinge sworne & Examined Deposeth & sayeth./

That hee Doeth knowe the severall parties in the tytle of the Interrogatories named for Complainante & Defendantes, And hee hath heard of Richard Gunnell in this Interrogatory Inquiqred of but never knewe him to his remembrance And more sayeth not to this Interrogatory./

That ʌhee hath Credibly vnderstoode & beleiueth that itt was an vsuall Custome & with and amongest the Masters & Cheefe Actors of the ffortune play house & other play houses (as this Deponent hath Credibly vnderstoode & beleiueth) to take youthes or boyes to bee theire Apprentices or Covenant servantes to serve & Abide with them for A Certaine
number of yeares, And that they Did vsually bynde such youthes and boyes as Apprentices to themselfeselues or others that were ffreemen of some trade or other, And that such boyes & servantes Did vsually Acte & play partes in Comedyes and Tragedyes att the fortune & other playe houses although they were not bound to Acte playes by Covenant in Expressed wordes, And that somme some of those boyes were made free of such particuler trades as their severall Masters vsed besides playeinge And this Deponent knoweth that one Iohn Wright was ʌbeinge bound as an Ap Apprentice to the said Complainante ʌfor a Certaine number of yeares to Learne & t the trade of A goldsmith Did Acte & play partes in Comedyes & Tragedyes, and that hee the said Iohn Wright was made free of the Trade of A Goldsmith by the said plaintiffe whc whoe vsed that trade besides playinge And further hee sayeth hee Cannott Depose to this Interrogatory./
To the rest &c./

head.title: Deposition of Henry Hamerton in Cane v. Wintershall

div.ab: Henry Hammerton Henry Hammerton: in italic scriptof the parishe of St Gyles Cripplegate in the Countie of Middlesex gentleman aged 53 yeares or thereaboutes beinge produced as A wittnes on the parte of the Complainante in this Cause was on the ffirst Day of ffebruary 1654, shewed in person to Mr one of the Clarkes in Mr office whoe is Clarke for the Defendantes in this Cause by William Bamfeild one of the sworne Clarkes of my office whoe then alsoe lefte a noate of the name tytle & place of aboade of the said Deponent with the said Mr And then afterwardes the same Day & yeare the said Deponent beinge sworne & Examined Deposeth & sayeth./

That hee Doeth knowe the severall parties in the tytle of the Interrogatories named for Complainante & Defendantes And hee Did knowe Richard Gunnell late of the parishe of St Gyles Cripplegate in the County of Middlesex gentleman Deceased in this Interrogatory Inquired of when hee was liveinge, And hee sayed sayeth that itt is aboute 24 yeares since hee the said Richard Gunnell Dyed soe neere as this Deponent remembreth the tyme./

That hee this Deponent beinge heretofore A player one of the players or Actors of Comedyes & Tragedyes in & about london Doeth knowe that it was ʌan vsuall & ordinary vsage & Custome vsed with & amongest the Actors of that the said ffortune play house & other playe houses in & Aboute London, to giue Mutuall bondes one to another, & for twoe three or foure of them or more to bynde themselues to some or one of their fellowes in A penall summe of money for the pament of C A Certaine summe of money att a day to come And this Deponent sayeth that hee this Depo hath entred into such bond himselfe, And hee sayeth that sinc such bondes as aforesaid were giuen & entred into Principally & to the end intent & purpose to keepe the said Actors together that they should not breake or leave theire C their Company & Acte att other playhouses, And this Deponen t sayeth that hee never knewe such bondes demaunded or put in suite, nor were such bondes to bee put in suite vnlesse vpon the departure of them soe bound & leaveinge their Company, And further he Deposeth not to these twoe Interrogatories./

head.title: Warrant for the Prince's Players

body.head: Item no. 53 of month (April) (Abstract of privy seal order)

note.add: Prince's Players Warrant to exercise their art & faculties &c

item.ab: A licence for the Princes players to exercise the art and facultie of playing tragedies Comedies histories pastorall es &c as well within their howse called the Fortune Fortune: in italic script in the Countie of Middlesex as elswhere in convenient places within this Realme of England for the recreacion of his Maiestes subiectes during his highness pleasure.

head.title: Warrant for the Elector Palatine's Men

item.ab: Right trusty and right welbeloved Cousin and Councellour we greet yow well, And will and commaund yow that vnder our privy Seale yow cause our lettres to be addressed to our Chauncellour of England Commaunding him that under our great Seale of England he cause our lettres to be made forth patents in forme followinge. Iames by the grace of God &c To all Iustices Mayours Sheriffes Bailiffes Constables Hedboroughes and all other our Officers and Lovinge subiectes greeting. Know ye that we of our especiall grace certaine knowledge and meere mocion have licensed & authorized And by theis presentes do license and authorize Thomas Downton William Bird Edward Iuby Samuell Rowle Charles Massey Humfrey Ieffs franck Grace William Cartwright Edward Colbrand William Parr, William Stratford, Richard Gunell [ Iohn Shanck and Richard Price servauntes to our sonne in Lawe the Elector Palatine and the rest of their Associates, to vse and exercise the art and facultie of playing Comedies Tragedies Histories Enterludes Moralls Pastoralls Stage Plaies and suche other like as they have already studied, or hereafter shall vse or study aswell for the recreacion of our Lovinge subiectes as for our solace and pleasure, when we shall thinke good to see them during our pleasure, And the said Comedies Tragedies, Histories , Enterludes Moralls Pastoralls Stage plaies and such like to shew and exercise publiquely to theire beste commoditie aswell within their now vsuall howse called the Fortune within our Countie of Middlesex, as also within any Towne halles or Moute halles or other convenient places within the libertie and freedome of any Citie vniversitie Towne or Borough whatsoever within our Realmes and dominions. Willing and commaunding yow and everie of yow as yow tender our pleasure, not onely to permitt and suffer them herein without any your Lettes hinderances or molestacions, Duringe our said pleasure, but also to be aiding and assisting vnto them if any wrong be to them offered, and to allow them such former curtesies as hath ben given to men of their place and quality, And also what further favour yow shall shew vnto them for our sake, We shall take kindly at your handes Prouided alwaies, And our will and pleasure is, That all authoritie power priviledges and profittes whatsoever belonging and properly appertayning to the Master of our Revelles in respect of his office, and every clause article or graunt conteyned within the Lettres patentes or commission which have heretofore ben graunted or directed to our Welbeloved servaunt Sir George Buck knight Master of our said Revelles shall ʌbe remaine and abide entire and in full force estate and vertue and in as ample sort as if this our Commission had never ben made In witnes whereof &c. And theis our Lettres shalbe your sufficient warrant and discharge in this behalf. Given vnder our Signet at our Pallace of Westminster the fourth day of Ianuary in the Tenth yeare of our Raigne of England ffraunce and Ireland, and of Scotland the six and fortith.

head.title: Affidavit in Markham v. Clayton

div.ab: Paull Tey (messenger of this Court) sent to warne diuerse persons at the sute of Gervis Markham gentleman sayeth that on or about the xxiijth day of May last he warned Richard Clayton, Richard Grace, William Stratford and Abraham Pedle gentlemen (all Actours at the fortune nere Golding lane) & one Robert Gough gentleman on the bancksyde in theire seuerall persons, and left seuerall notes in wryting for Raphe Keyes with his wief neere Doctours Commons, and for Iohn Trundle at his howse in Barbican, That all & euery of them should vpon the xxvth day of the same month make theire personall apparances in this court to answere A bill of complaint at the sute of Gervase Markham gentleman plaintiff

head.title: Licence for Prince’s Players

div.ab: A license for the Princes players to exercise the Art and faculty of playing Tragedies Comedies Histories Pastoralles &c. as well within their House called the Fortune in the County of middlesex As els where in Convenient places within this Relme of England, for the recreacion of his Maiestes Subiectes, During his highness pleasure procured by Sir Thomas Lake. Subscribed by the Master of the Revelles.

head.title: Committee for Advance of Money: Informations

body.head: f [141v] (20 September) (Information against delinquents and the Fortune playhouse)

ab.note:
heodore heodore: letter lost due tear at left margin
Allen

div.ab: Informacion per Iohn [ Theodore Allen -That Thomas Allein and Raph Allein Master and Warden of Gods guift Colledge in Dulwich in ye County of Surrey are Delinquentes

That Thomas Alleyn contrary to his oath taken when he was admitted Master &Warden of ye said Colledg by a contract vnder hand and seale resigned his place to one Iohn Allen a Mallignant who was formerly sequestred & fined & was since that againe sequestred for being a Captain & in actuall Armes against ye Parliament in ye late riseng in Kente with ye Lord Goreing

That whereas ye Fortune Playhouse being a demeane of ye said Colledge & in lease to one mr Lisle for ye payment of 120 li. per annum to ye said Colledge he ye said Mr Lisle desired (in regard ye state hath prohibited stage Playing house) that he might convert it ye said playhouse to some other vse whereby he might raise ye Rent due for ye same but they refused to suffer him so to doe but will haue their Rent paid paid still in ye Nature of a Playhowse which strange aversues to Ordinances of Parliament, & equity hath caused tedious & costly suites to ye much impoverishing of ye said Colledg & without some present remedy to ittes vtter vndoing

head.title: Playhouses in the Time of Charles I

body.head: sig B (The playhouses at the time of Charles I)

div.ab: IN the Reign of King Charles the First, there were Six Play Houses allow'd in Town: The Black-Fryars Company, His Majesty's Servants; The Bull in St. John's-street; another in Salisbury Court; another call'd the Fortune; another at the Globe; and the Sixth at the Cock-it in Drury-Lane; all which continu'd Acting till the beginning of the said Civil Wars.
